text:
Stuyvesant Street, and Second Avenue west side, showing St. Marks, P. E. church organized in 1791.

Charles L. Ritzman.
C. L. I.
About 1800's

21 Stuyvesant Street, north side, between Second and Third Avenues, showing the birthplace of the Honorable Hamilton Fish. This building was erected by his grandfather about 1800 as one of 4 homes built for his 4 daughters.

See Harpers Weekly - December 9, 1893 page 1169 New York Public Library *A. D. Vol 37 - July to December.

October 1938

George D. Ghinn

NEW YORK CITY.—DESECRATION OF THE VAULT OF A. T. STEWART—VIEW OF ST. MARK'S CHURCHYARD, SHOWING THE POSITION OF THE FAMILY VAULT.
St. Mark's Churchyard. Harper's Weekly, Nov. 16, 1878, p. 183.

(1) Stuyvesant Street, at the N.W. corner of Second Avenue, showing St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church, also known as St. Mark's in the Bowery. It was erected in 1795 and is the second oldest church edifice in Manhattan, standing on the site, where once stood the chapel built by Peter Stuyvesant, the last of the Dutch Governors whose bones rest beneath its floor. The present edifice was built in 1802.

Summer of 1924.

(2) The same at a later date.

September 21st, 1940

Photographs by,
P.L. Sperr,

(1) Stuyvesant Street, at the N.W. corner of Second Avenue, showing St. Mark's Protestant Episcopal Church, also known as St. Mark's in the Bowery. It was erected in 1795 and is the second oldest church edifice in Manhattan, standing on the site, where once stood the chapel built by Peter Stuyvesant, the last of the Dutch Governors whose bones rest beneath its floor. The present edifice was built in 1802.

St. Mark's-on-the-Bowerie. Second Avenue, west side, from Stuyvesant to 11th Streets. This church is an old New York landmark; in its yard lies the body of Peter Stuyvesant, last Dutch Governor of New Amsterdam. In the right foreground is seen the construction of a building on the former site of the Second Avenue Baptist Church. About 1928.

Brown Brothers, Photographers.

(1) Stuyvesant Street, north side, east from but not including Third, to and including Second Avenues. Shown are St. Mark's P.E. Church (N.W. corner of East 10th Street at Second Avenue), and the Second Avenue Baptist Church on the east side of Second Avenue, between East 10th and 11th Streets. On the right at the intersection of Stuyvesant Street and East 9th Street, appears the Hebrew Technical Institute.

April 16, 1928

P. L. Sperr

(2) The same, at a later date, showing in the foreground a three and one-half story building (No. 21), the birthplace of the Honorable Hamilton Fish. This structure was erected by his grandfather around 1800 and was one of four houses that he built for his four daughters. For further information see the Harpers Weekly of December 9, 1893, page 1169, New York Public Library *AD Vol. 37 July to December 1893.

May 21, 1934

P. L. Sperr

Stuyvesant Street, at the N.W. corner of Second Ave., showing St. Mark's Church (P.E.). The present church was consecrated in 1829 and under it lies buried Peter Stuyvesant, the last of the Dutch Colonial Governors, who died in 1682 and was laid there when the Chapel occupied the site. The bodies of Henry Slaughter, the English royal Governor, and Daniel Tompkins, early Governor of New York State also rest there. It is also known as "St. Mark's on the Bouwerie."

1936.

W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Writers Project.

St. Marks Church. 2nd Ave., w.s., from Stuyvesant to 11th St.

Federal Art Project, "Changing New York," photographs by Berenice Abbott.
